list_definition.definition: the hole or slit into which a button is put.
to catch someone’s attention and hold him in conversation

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He buttonholed me and began telling me the story of his life.

list_ex_of_english: The zona orbicularis acts like a buttonhole on the femoral head and assists in maintaining the contact in the joint.
He was exquisitely dressed with an orchid in his buttonhole, gold-topped cane and gloves.
Occasionally bars of buttonhole stitches are worked over fabric and net before both are cut away.
She has had a loss in her family lately, which perhaps accounts for the lack of triviality your lordship complains of in the buttonhole.
Lapels also have a buttonhole, intended to hold a boutonnire, a decorative flower.
Every day he arrived with a fresh red rose in his buttonhole.
Linen embroidered with silk and metallic thread, in a mix of counted and free-stitched stitches, including buttonhole, chain, double running, overcast, plaited braid, and square open work stitches.
The fabric is simply folded over and the buttonhole stitching secures the two layers (or three layers if there is an interlining).
